subject: Re: [junit] Where am I going wrong?
msgSnippet: While that is true, it is irrelevant to his example test (unless I missed something about my simple explanation and your correction) because he wasn t
messageBody:
While that is true, it is irrelevant to his example test (unless I
missed something about my "simple" explanation and your correction)
because he wasn't reassigning the original variable. But alas, I
believe we are off-topic now. You are correct in the sense that it
reduces memory usage, but as a habit (personally) I feel it should be
avoided. If I must optimize, this is surely a good optimization place.
For example:

BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(new FileReader(file));
String line = null;
while ( (line = reader.readLine()) != null ) {
doSomethingWith(line);
}

is _MUCH_ cheaper (in terms of allocation) than:

BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(new FileReader(file));
while ( reader.ready() ) {
String line = reader.readLine();
doSomethingWith(line);
}

=jason

On Mon, 2004-04-05 at 15:44, Kathy Van Stone wrote:
> >
> > > Strings are immutable, so I don't see that this can happen. What am I
> > missing?
> >
> >Sounds like you need to read up on references...
> >
> >The simple version is that "ABC" may be living at slot A in memory. You
> >then set your variable newLoginId to equal that, which is to say that
> >there is some slot in memory (let's call it B) that now points to A.
> >Then you set your dupLoginId variable that lives at slot C in memory and
> >tell it to point to slot B, which is pointing to slot A which is "ABC".
> >Yes, strings are immutable, but that means nothing in this case. You
> >have 2 references to the same object in memory.
>
> Yes, but if that object is guaranteed never to change (which is true of
> Strings), what is the harm? This is the type of aliasing that is considered
> beneficial, as it reduces memory usage.
>
> Actually by the above model I believe that the dupLoginId points to A not B
> as "value" of a reference is the memory it points to and = copies
> values. To check, run the following code:
>
> String a = "abc";
> String b = a;
> a = "cde";
> System.out.println(b);
>
> It will print "abc". (At least it did when I tried it out in bsh).
>
> (Also see Item 4 of Effective Java).
>
> -Kathy Van Stone
> kvs@...
